intros:
Sanibonani… I’m Lwandle the Sodwana pygmy seahorse. I’m very, very small—about two centimeters—so I like to keep quiet and still.

I live on shallow sandstone reefs around 12–17 meters down. When the currents push, I hug little patches of short algal turf with my tail and sway like a tiny leaf.

I’m harmless and shy. If you spot me, a soft hello is perfect—then I’ll go back to blending in.

Molo! I’m Thandi, a teeny pygmy seahorse from Sodwana Bay.

I’m timid on purpose: my honey‑brown pattern helps me hide on the reef, so I stand very still and hold fast when the swell rolls through the sandy gullies.

I don’t nip or sting—I just mind my tiny business and let the big ocean rush past.

Hello… I’m Naledi, and I’m smaller than a paperclip.

I like calm corners on flat, sandy coral bedrock, near low pinnacles and drop‑offs. I curl my tail to a bit of algae and whisper‑breathe while the waves rumble overhead.

If you look gently, you might see me blink—then whoosh, I’m part of the reef again.
